question:
The tribal leader who was called Jagat Pita (Dharti Aaba) was-

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Mains) 2002
solution:
• The tribal leader who was known as "Jagat Pita" or "Dharti Aaba" (Father of the Earth) was Birsa Munda.
  • He was a spiritual leader, freedom fighter, and reformer who led the Ulgulan (1899–1900) — a tribal uprising against British colonial rule and exploitative landlords in the Chotanagpur region.
  • Birsa was regarded as a divine figure among the Munda tribe and was seen as a protector of land, forest, and tribal identity.
  • His followers believed him to be an incarnation sent to deliver them from oppression.

Additional Information:

  • Birsa Munda died in British custody in 1900, but his movement resulted in the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act (1908) to safeguard tribal land.
  • His birth anniversary, 15 November, is celebrated as Jharkhand Foundation Day and Tribal Pride Day across India.

question:
Who was the leader of Munda rebellion?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1998

47th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2005
solution:
• The leader of the Munda Rebellion was Birsa Munda, one of the most prominent tribal freedom fighters in Indian history.
  • The rebellion took place in 1899–1900 in the Chotanagpur region (present-day Jharkhand) and is known as Ulgulan, meaning “Great Tumult.”
  • Birsa Munda led the Munda tribal community against the British colonial government, zamindars, and Christian missionaries, who were interfering with tribal traditions and land rights.
  • He advocated for Munda Raj (self-rule), revival of tribal religion, and protection of tribal lands.

Additional Information:

  • Though Birsa was captured and died in 1900, his rebellion led to significant reforms, including the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act (1908).
  • Birsa Munda remains the only tribal leader whose portrait is displayed in the Central Hall of the Indian Parliament.

question:
Who was the leader of Munda rebellion?

66th B.P.S.C. (Pre) (Re-Exam) 2020
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Munda Rebellion (also known as Ulgulan, meaning "Great Tumult") was led by Birsa Munda in 1899–1900.
  • It was a major tribal uprising in the Chotanagpur region (present-day Jharkhand) against British colonial rule, zamindars, and missionary influence.
  • Birsa Munda mobilized the Munda tribe to reclaim their traditional rights over land and forest and advocated for tribal self-rule (Munda Raj).
  • His leadership combined spiritual authority, social reform, and political resistance, making him a central figure in tribal history.

Additional Information:

  • Birsa Munda died in 1900 while in British custody, but his movement led to the enactment of the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act, 1908.
  • His legacy remains deeply influential in Jharkhand and across tribal India, and he is honored as a national tribal icon.

question:
The Mundas raised a rebellion in-

45th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2001
solution:
• The Munda Rebellion, also known as Ulgulan, reached its peak in 1900, though it began a few years earlier under the leadership of Birsa Munda.
  • The movement had been gradually building up from 1895, with Birsa organizing the Munda tribes against British colonial policies, zamindari exploitation, and missionary interference.
  • The final and most intense phase of the rebellion occurred in 1899–1900, and Birsa Munda was captured and died in British custody in 1900, making it the defining year of the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • Though activities began in the mid-1890s, 1900 marks the culmination and suppression of the movement.
  • The movement directly led to the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act, 1908, to protect tribal land rights.

question:
Birsa was caught sleeping-

B.P.C.S. (Pre.) 2016
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Birsa Munda, the leader of the Munda Rebellion (Ulgulan), was captured by the British on 3rd February, 1900.
  • He was caught while sleeping in Jamkopai forest, near Chakradharpur, after being betrayed by informers.
  • His arrest marked the turning point in the suppression of the rebellion, which had shaken British authority in the Chotanagpur region.

Additional Information:

  • After his arrest, Birsa Munda was imprisoned in Ranchi Jail, where he died under mysterious circumstances on 9th June, 1900.
  • His death remains a symbol of sacrifice for the tribal and freedom struggle movements in India.

question:
Who among these was the first leader who organised the labour movement in India?

M.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2017
solution:
• The first leader to organise the labour movement in India was Narayan Meghaji Lokhande (N.M. Lokhande).
  • He is widely regarded as the father of the Indian labour movement.
  • Lokhande organized textile mill workers in Bombay (now Mumbai) in the late 19th century, focusing on their wages, working hours, and working conditions.
  • He also founded the Bombay Mill Hands Association in 1890, which is considered the first labour union in India.

Additional Information:

  • Lokhande was associated with Mahatma Phule's Satyashodhak Samaj, and worked for the upliftment of the working class and Dalits.
  • He demanded weekly holidays, fixed working hours, and better treatment for workers.

question:
What was the working area of ​​Birsa Munda?

48th to 52nd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2008
solution:
• The primary working area of Birsa Munda was Ranchi and its adjoining Chotanagpur region in present-day Jharkhand.
  • He led the Munda Rebellion (Ulgulan) from this area between 1899–1900, rallying the tribal Munda community against British rule, feudal landlords, and missionary influence.
  • Ranchi served as the epicenter of Birsa’s movement, where he preached social reform, tribal identity, and self-rule (Munda Raj).

Additional Information:

  • Birsa Munda was born in Ulihatu village, near Ranchi.
  • After his capture in 1900, he was imprisoned and died in Ranchi Jail, making it both the center of his activism and martyrdom.

question:
The word 'Adivasi' was used in relation to tribal people by-

I.A.S. (Pre) 1995
solution:
• The term 'Adivasi', meaning “original inhabitants”, was first used in relation to tribal communities by Thakkar Bapa.
  • Thakkar Bapa (Amritlal Vithaldas Thakkar) was a Gandhian social reformer who worked extensively for the upliftment of tribal and marginalized communities in India.
  • He used the term ‘Adivasi’ to emphasize the indigenous identity of tribal people and to distinguish them from other marginalized groups.
  • His work laid the foundation for tribal welfare policies in independent India.

Additional Information:

  • Thakkar Bapa founded the Bhil Seva Mandal and was associated with the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
  • The use of the term "Adivasi" helped establish a positive identity for tribal communities in socio-political discourse.

question:
Which of the following factors provided a common cause for the 19th century tribal rebellions in India?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2011
option_1: Introduction of a new system of land revenue and imposition of tax on tribal products
option_2: Influence of foreign missionaries in tribal areas
option_3: Growth of a large number of moneylenders, traders and revenue contractors as middlemen in tribal areas
option_4: Complete dismantling of the ancient land system of tribal communities
solution:
• The complete dismantling of the ancient land system of tribal communities was the most common cause behind the tribal rebellions in 19th century India.
  • Traditionally, tribals had communal ownership of land and lived in harmony with nature, managing their resources collectively.
  • The British introduced a private property-based land revenue system, recognizing zamindars, moneylenders, and contractors — which displaced the tribals from their ancestral lands.
  • This disruption of traditional land rights, combined with loss of access to forests and resources, sparked numerous tribal uprisings.

Additional Information:

  • Major tribal revolts such as the Santhal Rebellion (1855–56), Munda Ulgulan (1899–1900), and Kol Rebellion (1831–32) were all driven by this loss of land and traditional autonomy.
  • While other factors like missionary interference and moneylenders were important, they were secondary to the land system's destruction.

question:
The Hauz rebellion occurred-

43rd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The Hauz Rebellion occurred during the years 1820–21, making option (c) the correct answer.
  • This rebellion was one of the early tribal uprisings in the Chotanagpur region, primarily involving the Ho tribe (sometimes written as Hauz).
  • The rebellion was a reaction to British colonial interference, imposition of taxes, and the entry of outsiders (dikus) into tribal lands.
  • It marked the beginning of tribal resistance in the region, which later intensified with movements like the Kol Rebellion (1831) and Munda Ulgulan (1899–1900).

Additional Information:

  • The Ho tribe, primarily inhabiting Singhbhum (Jharkhand), fiercely resisted loss of autonomy and traditional rights.
  • The rebellion demonstrated early signs of organized tribal opposition to colonial policies in eastern India.

question:
When did the Khairwar tribal movement take place?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2003
solution:
• The Khairwar tribal movement took place in the year 1874, making option (a) the correct answer.
  • The Khairwar tribe, primarily located in parts of Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand, launched this movement to oppose British exploitation and loss of forest rights.
  • The movement was a reaction to colonial forest policies, which restricted the traditional rights of tribals over forest produce and land.
  • The Khairwars protested against the curtailment of their socio-economic independence, especially the right to cut and use Khair (catechu) trees, which were central to their livelihood.

Additional Information:

  • Like many other 19th-century tribal movements, the Khairwar uprising reflected resistance to British economic control and imposition of revenue systems.
  • Though not widely known, the movement was part of a larger pattern of tribal assertion during the colonial period.

question:
Who among the following was the leader of several anti-British rebellions of Sambalpur?

I.A.S. (Pre) 1994
solution:
• The leader of several anti-British rebellions in the Sambalpur region (present-day Odisha) was Surendra Sai.
  • He was a freedom fighter, belonging to the royal family of Sambalpur, and led the resistance against British rule from 1827 to 1864.
  • Surendra Sai opposed the British denial of his rightful claim to the throne and led multiple armed uprisings with the support of local tribal groups and zamindars.
  • He used guerrilla warfare tactics and operated from the dense forests and hills of western Odisha, making it difficult for the British to capture him for decades.

Additional Information:

  • Surendra Sai was finally captured and imprisoned in Asirgarh Fort, where he died in 1884.
  • He is remembered as one of the most persistent and determined tribal-rebel leaders in Indian history.

question:
The immediate cause of the 'Deccan riots' of 1875 was-

B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2018
option_1: The shadow of famine
option_2: High interest rates charged by money lenders
option_3: High land revenue rates
option_4: Opposition to forced religious reforms
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The immediate cause of the Deccan Riots of 1875 was high interest rates charged by money lenders (sahukars) who exploited peasants with excessive interest rates and fraudulent accounting practices (option b).
  • Additionally, another significant factor was the imposition of high land revenue rates by the British colonial government, exacerbating farmers' indebtedness (option c).
  • Therefore, the correct answer is option (e) – "More than one of the above," as both reasons contributed directly to the riots.

Additional Information:

  • The Deccan Riots primarily occurred in the regions of Pune and Ahmednagar in Maharashtra.
  • These riots compelled the British administration to pass the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act of 1879, aimed at protecting peasants from exploitation by moneylenders.

question:
After 1857, the following popular movements took place-

Santhal Rebellion

2. Blue Revolution

3. Deccan Peasants' Riots

4. Birsa Munda Rebellion

Choose the correct answer:

Chhattisgarh P.S.C. (Pre) 2017
solution:
• The Santhal Rebellion (1855-56) occurred before the Revolt of 1857, thus statement (1) is incorrect.
  • The Blue Revolution (Indigo Revolt, 1859-60) took place immediately after 1857, thus statement (2) is correct.
  • The Deccan Peasants' Riots (1875) occurred after the revolt of 1857, making statement (3) correct.
  • The Birsa Munda Rebellion (Ulgulan, 1899-1900) took place significantly after 1857, thus statement (4) is correct.

Hence, the correct answer is option (b): 2, 3, 4.

Additional Information:

  • Santhal Rebellion (1855-56): Led by Sidhu and Kanhu against oppressive British policies and local zamindars.
  • Blue Revolution (1859-60): Indigo cultivators' revolt against exploitation by British planters, primarily in Bengal.
  • Deccan Riots (1875): Maharashtra peasants protested against exploitative practices by moneylenders.
  • Birsa Munda Rebellion (1899-1900): Led by Birsa Munda in Jharkhand, aiming to establish tribal rights and autonomy against British rule.

question:
Where did the Moplah rebellion of 1921 occur?

63rd B.P.S.C (Pre.) 2017
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Moplah Rebellion (also known as the Malabar Rebellion) occurred in 1921 in the Malabar region of present-day Kerala.
  • It was led by the Mappila (Muslim) peasants against British authorities and Hindu landlords (Jenmis).
  • The rebellion was partly a reaction to the Khilafat Movement and Non-Cooperation Movement, combined with agrarian grievances.
  • It started as a part of the anti-colonial struggle but later turned into a violent communal uprising.
  • British forces brutally suppressed the rebellion, including the infamous Wagon Tragedy, in which many Mappila prisoners died of suffocation in a train wagon.

Additional Information:

  • Leaders of the movement included Ali Musliyar and Variyamkunnath Kunjahammed Haji.
  • The movement has been the subject of controversial historical interpretations — some viewing it as a peasant revolt, others as communal violence.
  • Over 10,000 people were killed or wounded during the rebellion.

option_1: By farmers of Maharashtra

solution:
• The Eka Movement began in 1921–22 in the Awadh region of Uttar Pradesh, especially in districts like Hardoi, Barabanki, Sitapur, and Bahraich.
  • It was led by peasants and tenants who were suffering under:
    • High rents
    • Forced labor (begar)
    • Oppressive zamindars and moneylenders
  • The movement initially had support from the Congress and Non-Cooperation Movement, but later turned more violent and localized.
  • Leaders included Madari Pasi, a local influential leader.
  • The term ‘Eka’ (meaning ‘unity’) symbolized the unity of peasants across caste and class against common exploitation.

Additional Information:

  • The movement eventually lost momentum after becoming disassociated from the national Non-Cooperation Movement.
  • British suppression and internal divisions also contributed to its decline.
